section.title: How Derivatives Affect the Shape of a Graph

ul.li: Use the Increasing/Decreasing Test to determine the intervals over which a function is increasing or decreasing
Use the First Derivative Test and the Second Derivative Test to identify local extrema
Describe concavity of a function, estimate the intervals of concavity and location of inflection points
Use the Concavity Test to determine intervals over which a function is concave up or concave down and locate inflection points
Use derivatives to identify qualitative information about a function and use the information along with other given properties to sketch the graph of the function

theorem.title: Increasing/Decreasing
theorem.statement: Let f be a differentiable function on the interval (a,b). If f'(x) \gt 0 on (a,b), then f is increasing on (a,b). If f'(x) \lt 0 on (a,b), then f is decreasing on (a,b).

Sketch the graph of f, and visually determine where the function is increasing and decreasing.
Now, use the Increasing/Decreasing Test to determine the intervals where f is increasing and decreasing.

subsubsection.title: Local Extrema
subsubsection.p: Fermat's Theorem tells us that if we have a local max or min at input x = c, then c is a critical number of f. We need some more machinery in order to classify extrema.

theorem.title: First Derivative Test
theorem.statement: Suppose that c is a critical number of a continuous function f. If f' changes from positive to negative at c, then f has a local maximum at c. If f' changes from negative to positive at c, then f has a local minimum at c. If f' does not change sign around c, then f has no local maximum or minimum at c.

example.statement: Find the local maximum and minimum values of the function g(x) = x + 2\sin x on 0\leq x\leq 2\pi.
example.solution: The local max occurs at x=\dfrac{2\pi}{3} and the local min occurs at x=\dfrac{4\pi}{3}

example.statement: Let f(x) = 200 + 8x^3 + x^4. Find the intervals where f is increasing, decreasing, and identify local extrema of f.
example.solution: The function is increasing on (-6,0)\cup (0,\infty) and decreasing on (-\infty,-6). There is a local minmum at (-6,-232).

subsubsection.title: Concavity
subsubsection.p: The first derivative tells us information about where a function is increasing or decreasing, and where it has horizontal tangent lines. The second derivative tells us information about how a function bends.

definition.title: Concave Up/Concave Down
definition.p: If the graph of f lies above all of its tangents on an interval I, then it is said to be concave up on I; if f lies below all of its tangents on I, then it is said to be concave down on I.

definition.title: Inflection Point
definition.p: A point (c,f(c)) on a curve y = f(x) is called an inflection point if f is continuous there and the curve changes concavity.

example.solution: f''(x) \lt 0 on (-\infty,0) and f''(x) \gt 0 on (0,\infty). There is an inflection point at x=0.

example.statement: Let f(x) = x^3-3x^2-9x+4. Find the intervals where f is increasing and decreasing.
example.solution: f(x) is increasing on (-\infty,-1)\cup (3,\infty) and decreasing on (-1,3).

example.statement: Given the picture below, find the open intervals where f is increasing, decreasing, concave up, concave down. Identify the coordinates of any inflection points.
example.solution: The function is increasing on (1,3)\cup (4,6), decreasing on (0,1)\cup (3,4), concave up on (0,2), and concave down on (2,4)\cup (4,6). There is an inflection point at (2,3).

example.statement: The graph of the derivative, f', is given below. On what interval(s) is f increasing or decreasing? At what inputs does f have a local maximum or minimum?
example.solution: f(x) is increasing on (1,5) and decreasing on (0,1)\cup (5,6). There is a local max at x=5 and a local min at x=1.

theorem.title: Concavity Test
theorem.statement: If f''(x) \gt 0 for all x in I, then the graph of f is concave up on I. If f''(x) \lt 0 for all x in I, then the graph of f is concave down on I

example.statement:
Let f(x) = x^3 - 3x.
Find the intervals where f(x) is increasing and decreasing.
Identify the local maxima and minima of f(x).
Where is f concave up? Where is it concave down?
Identify any inflection points of f.

solution.ol:
f(x) is increasing on (-\infty,-1)\cup (1,\infty) and decreasing on (-1,1)
The max occurs at (-1,2) and the min occurs at (1,-2)
f(x) is concave up on (0,\infty) and concave down on (-\infty,0)
f(x) is concave up on (0,\infty) and concave down on (-\infty,0)
The inflection point is at (0,0)

theorem.title: Second Derivative Test
theorem.p: Suppose f'' is continuous near c, and f'(c) = 0. If f''(c) \gt 0, then f has a local minimum at c. If f''(c) \lt 0, then f has a local maximum at c.

Sketch the graph of a function that satisfies the criteria outlined below:
Vertical asymptote at x = 0.
f'(x) \gt 0 if x \lt -2, f'(x) \lt 0 if x \gt -2 (for x\neq 0).
f''(x) \lt 0 if x \lt 0, f''(x) \gt 0 if x \gt 0.

f'(5) = 0, f'(x) \lt 0 when x \lt 5, f'(x) \gt 0 when x \gt 5
f''(2) = 0, f''(8) = 0, f''(x) \lt 0 when x \lt 2 or x \gt 8, f''(x) \gt 0 for 2\lt x\lt 8.

Find the intervals on which \sin x + \cos x is increasing/decreasing on [0,2\pi], the local maximum and minimum values of the function on the interval, and the intervals of concavity/inflection points.
example.solution: The function is increasing on \lrpar{0,\dfrac{\pi}{4}}\cup \lrpar{\dfrac{5\pi}{4},2\pi}, decreasing on \lrpar{\dfrac{\pi}{4},\dfrac{5\pi}{4}}, concave up on \lrpar{\dfrac{3\pi}{4},\dfrac{7\pi}{4}}, and concave down on \lrpar{0,\dfrac{3\pi}{4}}\cup \lrpar{\dfrac{7\pi}{4},2\pi}. The local max occurs at \lrpar{\dfrac{\pi}{4},\sqrt{2}} and the local min occurs at \lrpar{\dfrac{5\pi}{4},-\sqrt{2}}.

example.statement: Find the local maximum and minimum values of f(x) = \dfrac{x^2}{x-1} using the First and Second Derivative Tests.
example.solution: The local max is at x=0 and the local min is at x=2
